channel.title: New computer setup
channel.description:
So what I'd like to do is get the best motherboard I can with the least amount of components.
I have a question: If I buy a motherboard which says it supports ddr3 1066/1333/1600/2000 would I be able to put my old ram in which is ddr2 and probably less than 1066mhz? answer from budda Budda: no Budda: is ddr2 ddr3? Budda: no Budda: idiet noob
Okay so at the moment I've got my heart set on this motherboard: [img]http://static.scan.co.uk/Images/Products/1288237-c.jpg[/img] http://www.scan.co.uk/products/asus-rampage-iii-gene-intel-x58-s1366-pci-e-20-%28x16%29-ddr3-2200%28oc%29-sata-6gb-s-sata-raid-matx
I mean look at that shit, it's beautiful
Would this be a good option if I'm going to be adding stuff to as I go along (e.g. some day i might buy a load more ram, or I might get a newer graphics card)

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Ollie:

because probably in a year a new socket will be out, rendering your mobo quite pointless for upgrades on your current system.

I doubt the CPU will become the bottleneck, for a couple of years.

Read full topic

item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

Think it just means if you want to play certain streamed HD movies from the companies or local versions they won’t run unless you have sandy bridge chip, but for thongs like pirated movies and stuff and other films I think they would be unaffected

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

Don’t get an amazing computer when you don’t actually need the power. Unless you are doing resource intensive projects regularly ie Rendering/Video Editing/Maxing out Crysis2 then it really isn’t worth the money. I spent around 400 pounds ungrading my desktop and it runs amazingly fast but in all honestly I don’t really need it, it overkills for most of my games and I mainly use it to browse the internet and do light work.

Just think if you really need to spend your money on this, and if your money could be better spent elsewhere.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“shrogg, post:19, topic:374702”]it may not have looks but guess what it does
it supports SLI >>AND<< CROSSFIRE, and it even allows you to mix a ATI graphics card And a nvidia card together to get a slicroffire thing going :D[/quote]
I’ve been hearing that all the new sandybridge boards have this ability. Awesomeness

Still waiting till 9th of January and gonna have a good look around for the best motherboard. I’m going to be getting the intel i5 2500k, it’s £100 cheaper than the i7 and is about 99% the same as the i7. Also unlocked.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:17, topic:374702”]Id just pick all your components at the same time with the option to upgrade those components in the future. A couple of years ago I picked out a really expensive lga 775 socket motherboard with the hopes of getting the latest and greatest processor in the future only to find out that it was basically not going to get me to the top once they released the new socket 1366 and 1156. Then I had to buy another motherboard anyway.

EDIT: My bad I just noticed that you need a new motherboard because of your other topic, I would just buy one that is cheapest that will hold all of your components and still function well. Probably in the 100 dollar range.[/quote]
Eh I kinda want a snazzy new computer anyway. I have this netbook to do all my work I need.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Id just pick all your components at the same time with the option to upgrade those components in the future. A couple of years ago I picked out a really expensive lga 775 socket motherboard with the hopes of getting the latest and greatest processor in the future only to find out that it was basically not going to get me to the top once they released the new socket 1366 and 1156. Then I had to buy another motherboard anyway.

EDIT: My bad I just noticed that you need a new motherboard because of your other topic, I would just buy one that is cheapest that will hold all of your components and still function well. Probably in the 100 dollar range.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

WHYYY buy a £170 motherboard man, I bought a £90 motherboard when I built this rig and I could have got an equally good mobo for £50. There’s no need for a decent mobo, just get one with a decent amount of sata connections and you’re good to go.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

That seems awful expensive for a motherboard. Also, mini-atx might cause you problems later if you try to fit a big card in there. Like my 8800GTX would probably not fit at all, it’s huge. Otherwise you need to figure out what you have to spend, and go from there, you can spend a few hundred, or a few thousand, I’m sure you know that though.

My 8800gts was huge when I got it but it actually fitted in to my mini-atx quite snugly. I assume the gts is about the same size as the gtx, very big.

For now I’ve decided on getting the £170 mini-atx motherboard with an intel i7 £210 processor and some cheap ddr3 ram, however I’m going to leave it a few days and see if anything is on sale on boxing day.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:

[quote=“thepinksock, post:10, topic:374702”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=470664.msg3442304#msg3442304 date=1293154611]
because probably in a year a new socket will be out, rendering your mobo quite pointless for upgrades on your current system.
[/quote]
surely with that logic I’m better off not buying a new computer at all?[/quote]

exactly my point, get the main components you want to get now. dont wait to upgrade them later on.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

The sandy bridge processors by Intel will be out in the first quarter of next year, making it the biggest step since the original i7.

But, it is unlikely you’ll have any performance problems with the x58 CPU for a few years yet. You’re right though, when it comes to computers - waiting for new stuff will just have you waiting forever.

Read full topic

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Mopman:

Pick motherboard after deciding what you want to do CPU and Ram wise not the other way around

:s Why. What I want to do cpu and ram wise is have the choice to upgrade in a year or two without finding out my motherboard doesn’t support it because it’s too old. If I go with this miniatx one I posted above I assume being able to support x58 will last longer than any other board I get. It also has usb 3.0, and sata6 which seem to all be the new things.

So really I think the rampage gene is my best bet

Read full topic

Any socket 1366 CPU on the x58 chipset, yes. Basically, what you’d be looking at is the i7 9xx range.

item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Thug-life:

Remember, you’ll also need an x58 CPU (currently Intel’s most expensive CPU line).

I am a noob at this, but I assume the board is socket 1366 so that tells me I can fit any socket 1366 intel CPU. Is this right? p.s. get on irc so i can bug you about this directly

item.title: New computer setup
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Don’t buy internal components based on looks. And I’m not 100% sure, but I’m 99% sure that ddr2 ram will not work in a ddr3 mobo, it probably won’t even fit. Keep in mind that a CPU can fry your otherwise working mobo, so I don’t know if you want to try to reuse your old CPU or not. RAM is still pretty cheap isn’t it? So I’d just go with ddr3 when building a new one. You can reuse your existing graphics card probably. Otherwise I’d get a new mobo, ram, and probably CPU if you can.

Yeah hell no would I try putting my current cpu into a beautiful board like this. Yeah I will at first buy the cheapest ram that will fit it. I’m also sure my 8800gts will fit into this nicely.
My main priority is to get a motherboard which I know will last me a good few years that I can add things to as I get more money.

Also I obviously wont choose a board just on looks, I meant beautiful in the way it has so much on it.

Now I’ve found this a miniatx version of a much beefier board called rampage 3 extreme.

So do I want to spend £270 on this:

http://www.scan.co.uk/products/asus-rampage-iii-extreme-rog-x58-s1366-ddr3-(2200-oc)-sli-xfire-usb3-sata-6gbps-8ch-audio

or do I want to save myself £100 and get this for £170:

http://www.scan.co.uk/products/asus-rampage-iii-gene-intel-x58-s1366-pci-e-20-(x16)-ddr3-2200(oc)-sata-6gb-s-sata-raid-matx

Read full topic

Keep in mind that a CPU can fry your otherwise working mobo, so I don’t know if you want to try to reuse your old CPU or not. RAM is still pretty cheap isn’t it? So I’d just go with ddr3 when building a new one. You can reuse your existing graphics card probably. Otherwise I’d get a new mobo, ram, and probably CPU if you can.
